reviewText: If you are looking for a faithful rendition of the game show, you might need to look elsewhere.\n\nA port of what appears to be the Nintendo 3DS version of the 2015 revival, 5th Grader takes you back to school in answering 10 questions (and unlike the 2015 revival, has no icons" like the tv series
date: let alone soundtrack or Foxworthy V/O)\n\nThe positive is the game is VERY fast and you can speed right though
recommended: either thanks to being able to skip all the "showtime" or because of the ticking clock in answering. And the questions have thus-far have not been repeated
hoursPlayed: and are of similar style of the ones on the show.\n\nThe game play is the same as the show - pick a kid
voteText: answer questions
helpfulPercent: get up the millionaire-style ladder. However
votesHelpful: what makes this different is - the game encourages you to "go to school" to upgrade the classmates in some sort of cookie clicker game to upgrade the curriculum.\n\nIt's not "Funny Bad" for your funny let's play youtube channel
votesFunny: it's maybe worthy of a buy if you just feel compelled to pick-up every version of 5th Grader.\n\nIf you could find a copy of "Make The Grade" you're better off
column17: I suggest grinding it out in the "School" mode if you want to make sure the "cheats" you get are of any use.\n\nAlso
column18: that techno soundtrack in the background gets very annoying."

reviewText: What is Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?"?\n\n[tl;dr: Review is negative because of the questions not being correct in many cases. Until this is patched
date: even if you know the correct answer in at least 2 cases there is an outright wrong answer and many more are badly worded but still solvable by choosing the least wrong answer or the one for what you think they try to ask.]\n\n"Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?" is a trivia question game that has me break the rules of orthography to keep my usual review beginning. Also it is a license game of an U.S. American game show that runs in TV and has like all trivia game shows some funny clips you can watch on Youtube. Unfortunately
recommended: the game is highly unpolished although it also brings a motivating feature.\n\nThe gameplay is done with the mouse entirely. You play as a contestant that can inexplicably (read: Gameplay and Story Segregation) participate on the game show as often as he wants. Now the price money in this one is not only a high-score number
hoursPlayed: but can be used to improve the school your helpers in the game show come from.\n\nFirst of all
voteText: the graphics and sound are both forgettable. Music - nope! So you go through menus with the charme of classroom drawings and one 3D screen where you see five schoolkids and the host. Of course there is nobody else who attends. I hate to say it
helpfulPercent: but even the very dumbed down "Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? Special Edition" has better graphics.\n\nThe gameplay
votesTotal: is where a trivia game is succesful or not. There is not much to do
votesFunny: but a wide variety of questions is necessary. I played only a few games
commentsCount: and the questions did not repeat yet. So what is the bad news? Well
column16: the questions are at a rate of estimated one in 20 simply questionable. This is not to an extent that it stops you from solving most questions once you accept the moon logic of choosing the least wrong answer instead of the right one. For example
column18: although desire is much stronger than dislike. The - unlisted - answer disgust would have been more appropriate
column19: but still a bit off. In my very first game I had a completely wrong answer even - 37.713 divided by 10 is 3.7713
column20: I thought. It was 377.13 however. This is in addition to ambiguous questions that at least don't offer the wrong answer. How much is 4 over 12? The correct answer is of course -8
column21: but the game wants you to add 4 to 12
column22: making it 16. I managed to choose this correctly
column23: but it still is annoying to have questions not clearly named. Often you are supposed to know a biggest city
column24: usually it is the capital. I didn't check for all if it is the biggest city
column25: but once you have it in the spelling category where you have Barcelona and Madrid both spelled correctly
column26: requiring the additional knowledge that Madrid is bigger. Those are only small issues
column27: but they add up.\n\nAfter you answered the first 10 questions correctly
column29: 000 dollars - something that also can be done at any previous step
column30: although it wouldn't make any sense at the first or sixth question) or opt to see the million dollar question. You are presented with the category before you decide if you want to try it. Once you see the question
column32: and your only safety is at 25
column33: 000 dollar. In the whole game except this question you can also use three jokers. Two can be activated: Peeking at the answer or letting your pupil choose the answer. The third one is automatic: When you answer wrong
column34: your pupil can save you by answering right. This is a nice concept not seen in other games. In the final question this is impossible. If you go for the million
column35: you are on your own (or of course cheat
column36: like it always is possible at such games
column37: by looking up the answer while the clock ticks down).\n\nWhen you won some money
column38: you can rinse and repeat. Alternatively you can upgrade the school or hold events to learn more about your pupils
column39: so they gain new fields of interest or dislike possibly at semi-random or possibly just unlocked in a linear way. Upgrading the school makes people better
column40: for example having a science lab helps with science questions
column41: and having math equipment helps with math questions. I can only hope this was not also based on real elementary schools. As a nice bonus you gain offline money
column42: trickling in at a dollar or more per second. Upgrading the school generates a small but permanent bonus that way also
column43: meaning less grind by playing through the game. So you eventually unlock new wings and get access to more pupils
column44: until you eventually know all 30 of them. Wait
column45: so the more money you have
column46: the more teaching you do?\n\nThe more money you have
column47: the more teaching you do! Thanks! Finally I understand! We don't work to live
column48: we live to work! We must invest money into our companies so they allow us to do more unpaid work for them!\n\nJoke aside
column49: this grants you higher trickling money
column51: making the billionaire achievement (read: Exactly What It Says on the Tin) easy enough if you wait long enough. Is this motivating? Or to ask differently...\n\nWould I recommend this game? Well
column52: unfortunately not. It's like playing an idle game
column53: addicting to a degree but repetitive. It's the small grind for the ten minutes of time in-between
column54: like most trivia games it is a casual one
column55: and it would be nice at this. But then there are the questions that are so blatantly distracting
column56: ambiguous or even wrong. They are often challenging even to me
column57: and at one point I even learnt that Y is a vowel (which was not a mistake in the game). So yes
column58: the game would be nice with the questions corrected
column60: with a motivating idle minigame that improves the jokers you hopefully don't need. Even with all the technical badness it could have enough potential just in the core gameplay to be good. Unfortunately for now a major patch would be necessary that revisits all questions. Or to end with another reference to an addicting website: The game feels almost finished

reviewText:
First off I would like to say that I find it amusing that, at the time of writing, one of the user-defined game tags for this title is Psychological Horror.

I got this game in an Indie Gala bundle containing 12 games for a total of $2.89. I feel bad for the saps who've paid the asking price for this game. It's a rather bland representation of the show; there are no voice-overs, the soundtrack is tedious and the repetitive nature of the title makes the game quickly become boring. The graphics are also that of Nintendo DS capacity, which is a given seeing as this is a port from the handheld system.

Aside from the typical show" style game play (called Primetime)
date: you also have a School mode where you can upgrade various curriculum to make your students smarter and host events to learn their likes/dislikes/strengths/weaknesses. This will play a semi-crucial part in whether or not you succeed when you don't know the answer to a question.\n\nEven though there are a very large amount of questions available
recommended: the game itself just okay. It's good for wasting low amounts of time here and there. You probably won't get more than 3-4 hours of enjoyment from it. Don't bother at its full price
hoursPlayed: and don't go in expecting too much.\n\nRating: 2.5/5.0 - It's not awful
voteText: but it's not great.Belphegore's Hell House Reviews (Group)"

reviewText:
I really like trivia games and I rather enjoyed the original game version of Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader.  Unfortunately, this version has zero spoken dialog, five seconds of obnoxious electronic disco music on an endless loop, a horrible non-scalable interface that requires you to click many times for each question, etc.  This game also features a font in the style of hand-written print and the worst kerning I've ever seen; numeric equations are indecipherable, even for a credible mathematician.  The worst, and most unforgivable, issue with the game is that the questions are garbage.  Seriously, I lost three of my first four games on the game's belief that the following statements are true:

86.777 / 100 = 867.77
A liter is a measure of mass
The word detective is defined as member of the police force"
I lost the fourth game because I couldn't guess the details of Zambia's struggle for independence - information not typically included in fifth grade curriculum
date: but I'm smarter than a fifth grader.  I'm not so sure that the game's designers can make the same claim."

reviewText:
This is the quiz game based on the TV series of the same name.

The game content could be easily delivered over HTML - there's no sense in making a PC game about it.

Gameplay is boring quiz content - many of the questions are insultingly geocentric to the USA.

Graphics can't be changed - you're forced to run in windowed mode.

Technical limitations, lack of gameplay beyond what can be achieved with HTML and geocentricity make this impossible to recommend.

reviewText: I think this game is very entertaining!  There is the standard gameplay from the show, and a School section. This section lets you upgrade your students grades in the 4 subjects (Math, Science, Social studies, and Literature) with the money you gain from winning. There is also a multiplayer mode, which I have yet to try out! While there are some flaws, you have to remember that this game was uploaded to Steam yesterday. Hopefully updates are to come!!

-The storyline is great, Jeff Foxworthy tells a great story

Be sure to pick this game up, it's really good.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GAnDQ1mW9dk
So you think you're a total Know-It-All, don't you? Well Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader 2015 Edition is going to test your Mind to see how much you know about what you were thought in school. Despite using the Nintendo 3DS Engine, to be fair, Ludia did make the iOS Version while UbiSoft made the PS2 Version of the game, which are really fun to play. Answer every single Question & play through an entire game exactly as shown Primetime TV.

If you're stuck you can cheat by Peek or Copy to get the desired answer but be careful, you only got ONE Safeguard in case you make an error via incorrect answer, but if you did everything right in your mind and Memory then you could be Smarter than a 5th Grader!
